intro: Zanthoxylum naranjillo var. angustifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaf prickly ash, is a deciduous shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Rutaceae family, which includes citrus plants, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces red, fleshy berries that are edible for birds and small mammals, aiding in seed dispersal. Its bark and leaves contain bioactive compounds, making it of interest in traditional medicine and phytochemical research. The narrow, lance-shaped leaves and thorny stems are distinctive features that help identify the species in its natural habitat.
